item.title: As Death Toll Surges in Iran, Leaders Take Tough Line Against Protesters
item.description: Despite an internet blackout, reports are emerging of a rise in deadly violence as protests spurred by economic woes have snowballed into a mass movement.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran at a news conference in Tehran in 2024.

item.title: Trump Wants Greenland — but He’s Not Alone in the Arctic Tug of War
item.description: For decades, an Arctic archipelago called Svalbard has served as a rare refuge of international cooperation. Those days are over.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Sarah Hurtes, Louise Krüger and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: A great power competition is intensifying in the Arctic, and not only for Greenland.

item.title: A Russian Videographer Reveals How Putin Shapes the Next Generation
item.description: Pavel Talankin was a school events coordinator and videographer. When Russia overhauled the curriculum to make students into patriotic soldiers, he kept his camera rolling. The footage became a film that is shortlisted for an Oscar.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m just standing there filming and I understand that what’s getting into the camera isn’t just a lesson, but history,” Pavel Talankin said.

item.title: Israeli Police Question Top Netanyahu Aide Over Leaked Document Case
item.description: Tzachi Braverman, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s chief of staff, was detained for questioning on Sunday over accusations that he sought to impede an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Ohad Zwigenberg/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tzachi Braverman (standing), the chief of staff to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, was interviewed by the police on Sunday.

item.title: Syrian Military Takes Aleppo Neighborhoods After Clashes With Kurds
item.description: The takeover ended one of the worst outbreaks of violence between the central government and the Kurdish-led forces since the end of the civil war just over a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Adri Salido/Getty Images
item.media:description: Soldiers of the Syrian army in Aleppo on Saturday, following clashes between government forces and Kurdish fighters.

item.title: Trump Shakes up Latin American Politics
item.description: The U.S. capture of Nicolás Maduro has divided the region. But every nation wants to avoid being next.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government supporters calling for the release of Nicolás Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, last week.

item.title: Trump Threats and Venezuela Strike Leave Mexico Agonizing Over How to Respond
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum and her inner circle have been grappling with the right tone to strike in the country’s response to the Venezuela strike for fear of antagonizing the White House.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and James Wagner
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico has tried to thread a narrow diplomatic needle in the aftermath of the U.S. strike in Venezuela.

item.title: Schools in Occupied Ukraine Aim to Turn Children Into Russian Nationalists
item.description: Required lessons are heavy on militarism and pro-Russian, anti-Ukrainian propaganda. Some people make an arduous escape, partly to avoid the indoctrination.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tetiana, 37, and her two daughters after crossing from Belarus into Ukraine, in December.

item.title: India’s Ties With Bangladesh Fray as Elections Loom
item.description: A simmering dispute between the neighbors, who share one of the largest land borders in the world, has escalated with diplomatic protests and a sports boycott.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Sonu Mehta/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and then Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh in New Delhi in 2024. Ms. Hasina was ousted by a protest movement and fled to India, which has since been criticized by Bangladesh’s interim government and the protesters who ousted her for refusing to hand her over to face justice at home.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Enlists U.S. Troops to Bring a Rogue Ship Back
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez got American help with the return of an oil tanker linked to one of her political rivals that had left the country without authorization.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, the interim leader of Venezuela, in the country’s capital, Caracas, on Monday.

item.title: Why Putin Went Quiet When Challenged by Trump Over Venezuela
item.description: For the Russian leader, courting President Trump to secure a favorable resolution in Ukraine, and possibly more, is far more important.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne, Valerie Hopkins and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a news conference with President Trump in August in Anchorage.

item.title: Why Are Iranians Protesting? What to Know About the Unrest.
item.description: Demonstrations that began as outrage over the economy have spread across the country, amid an escalating crackdown by the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Leily Nikounazar, Farnaz Fassihi and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken from a social media post on Friday shows demonstrators gathered in Tehran, Iran’s capital.

item.title: How Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s Leader, Became Vital to Trump’s Plans for the Country
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez, a guerrilla’s daughter, started out as a provocateur. She pivoted to revive a ravaged economy, making her vital to U.S. plans to run Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, then Venezuela’s vice president, during an interview last year.

item.title: Trump Eyes Greenland, and Europe Figures Its Best Bet Is a Negotiation
item.description: European officials were stunned that President Trump restated his desire for Greenland after a yearlong effort to dissuade him, according to diplomats and others.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Eric Schmitt, Steven Erlanger and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nuuk, the capital of Greenland. “The real question is, by what right does Denmark assert control over Greenland?” Stephen Miller, one of President Trump’s closest aides, said this week.

item.title: Deposed Shah’s Son Hopes Trump Will Put Iran Regime ‘Down for Good’
item.description: Reza Pahlavi, once the crown prince of Iran, says protesters there have been emboldened by President Trump suggesting that he could take military action.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joe Klamar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Austria displayed images of Reza Pahlavi during a rally on Sunday in support of nationwide protests in Iran.

item.title: Famed Nigerian Author Blames Death of Toddler Son on Negligent Care
item.description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie is accusing a private hospital in Lagos of administering an overdose of a sedative, prompting an outpouring of complaints by Nigerians about their health care system.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Ismail Auwal
item.media:credit: Schaun Champion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie at her home in Maryland in February.

item.title: Mass Protests in Iran and Trump’s Threats
item.description: A question now hangs over the country: Is Iran the next target of an emboldened U.S. president?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: UGC, via Associated Press

item.title: Malaysia and Indonesia Block Access to Grok Because of Sexually Explicit Content
item.description: Grok, the chatbot created by Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence company, has produced a flood of explicit images featuring real people in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prompt page for Grok, the A.I. chatbot made by xAI.

item.title: Are You Fat Enough to Play in This Soccer League?
item.description: Man v Fat, a soccer league founded in Britain a decade ago, is expanding in the United States, bringing with it a self-deprecating approach to shedding pounds.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: It’s all fun, games and fat-burning as Fat Man United competes against Totten-Ham and Cheese in suburban Dallas.

item.title: Latin America Reacts to Trump’s Interventionism
item.description: Jack Nicas, our Mexico City bureau chief, walks us through the ways Latin American leaders are reacting to Trumps recent attack on Venezuela
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Rebecca Suner, James Surdam and Edward Vega

item.title: Australia Wildfires Burn Nearly 900,000 Acres
item.description: Blazes in the state of Victoria have destroyed hundreds of structures, including homes, and killed one person, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Michael Currie/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a burning forest near Longwood, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: Death Toll Grows as Nationwide Protests Rock Iran for a Third Night
item.description: Antigovernment unrest that began two weeks ago has intensified in recent days, as has violence.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Malachy Browne
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: UGC, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still from video shared on social media on Friday that has been verified by The New York Times showing crowds around an open fire in Tehran, Iran’s capital.

item.title: Nearly 13,000 Irish Passports Are Recalled Over ‘Technical Issue’
item.description: The recall affects passports issued between Dec. 23 and Jan. 6, Ireland’s Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Shutterstock
item.media:description: A “technical issue with a software update” may prevent Irish citizens from traveling with passports issued between Dec. 23 and Jan. 6, the country’s foreign affairs department said.

item.title: Machado Offered Trump Her Nobel, but Prize Institute Says It’s Not Allowed
item.description: After María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, offered her Nobel Peace Prize to President Trump, the Norwegian Nobel Institute said it cannot be “transferred to others.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, offered to give her Nobel Peace Prize to President Trump, who has long coveted the award.

item.title: Acquired Tastes
item.description: The dream of cohabitating with a group of friends is an attractive fantasy, but we can benefit from its lessons, regardless of our living situation.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Chrystia Freeland Resigns as a Member of Canada’s Parliament
item.description: Once a powerful force under Justin Trudeau, Chrystia Freeland ended her time in politics on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chrystia Freeland, who resigned from Parliament on Friday, at her home in Toronto.

item.title: Inside Iran’s Protests: How a Plunging Currency Set Off Wide Unrest
item.description: In a serious challenge to Iran’s authoritarian government, angry protests have spread from the markets and universities of major cities to the impoverished towns in the hinterland.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Sanam Mahoozi, Sanjana Varghese and Jon Hazell
item.media:credit: Footage posted on Jan. 9, via AFP and Reuters

item.title: I.C.C. Judges Denounce Effect of Trump’s Sanctions
item.description: President Trump’s retaliation against top officials at the International Criminal Court has shut them out of American services and made even routine daily tasks a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.media:credit: Peter Dejong/Associated Press
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague. U.S. sanctions come at a time when the court is investigating claims of atrocities in Afghanistan, Libya, Myanmar, Sudan, Ukraine and Venezuela, as well as Gaza.

item.title: After President’s Capture, U.S. and Venezuela Explore Restoring Diplomatic Ties
item.description: The move embodied the contradictions and fast-changing nature of the two countries’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2019.

item.title: Trump Urges Oil Companies to Speed Work in Venezuela
item.description: The president met with executives on a day when the U.S. seized another tanker carrying Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Eric Schmitt and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at a meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Iran Convulsed in Second Night of Nationwide Protests
item.description: Large marches against the government occurred despite an internet blackout and threats of a severe crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators marched in Tehran in an image taken from a social media post that was shared on Thursday.

item.title: Mohammed Harbi, Who Rewrote Algeria’s History, Dies at 92
item.description: He was an official in the revolutionary government, then, after the country won independence from France, was imprisoned and eventually wrote from exile.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Outside Prisons in Caracas, Venezuelans Anxiously Await Release of More Political Detainees
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government said it would release an “important number” of imprisoned people, but only nine have been confirmed freed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members awaiting the release of prisoners outside El Helicoide, a notorious prison in the center of Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Take Greenland ‘the Hard Way’
item.description: The president continued to advance an imperialist vision of American foreign policy, where the U.S. can dominate neighboring countries “whether they like it or not.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at the meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Hessy Levinsons Taft, Jewish Baby on Cover of Nazi Magazine, Dies at 91
item.description: Without her parents’ knowledge, her portrait was entered as a prank in a contest in 1935 to represent the ideal Aryan infant — and she won.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: A Look at Iran’s Antigovernment Protests
item.description: Protests have rocked Iran in recent weeks, and the country’s supreme leader has threatened to escalate a crackdown on demonstrators. Erika Solomon, our bureau chief for Iran and Iraq, discusses what’s fueling the protests with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Katrin Bennhold, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, Parin Behrooz and Sanjana Varghese

item.title: An Up-Close Look at the Thwaites Glacier
item.description: From an icebreaker sailing near the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica, our photographer has captured the many faces of the ice.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: With Missile Strike on Ukraine, Putin Delivers a Warning to Europe
item.description: A nuclear-capable missile fired into Ukraine near Poland sent a message to Europe days after its leaders agreed to postwar security guarantees, Russian analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to an apartment building in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, after a strike on Friday.

item.title: What Is El Helicoide, the Infamous Torture Prison in Venezuela?
item.description: As Venezuela’s interim authorities began to release political prisoners, some of their families raced to the notorious prison that symbolized Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian rule.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Sulbarán and James Wagner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: El Helicoide seen in Caracas on Thursday. It was first conceived as a futuristic mall before being repurposed to hold prisoners.

item.title: Yemeni Separatists Say They Are Disbanding, but Move Is in Dispute
item.description: A delegation from the Southern Transitional Council in Riyadh announced its dissolution, but members abroad rejected the news amid fears it was not voluntary.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar, Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Fawaz Salman/Reuters
item.media:description: Soldiers on Thursday in Aden, Yemen, outside the headquarters of the Southern Transitional Council, a separatist group that has sought to create an independent state in Yemen’s south.

item.title: Prosecutor Asks for Owner of Swiss Bar Hit by Deadly Fire to Be Detained
item.description: The request came after hours of questioning of the bar’s co-owners. Some 40 people died in the fire that broke out during a New Year’s celebration.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Umit Bektas/Reuters
item.media:description: Jacques and Jessica Moretti, the owners of the Swiss bar that burned in a deadly fire last week, in Sion, Switzerland, on Friday.

item.title: Freed Venezuelan Political Prisoner Called Maduro’s 2024 Victory a Fraud to His Face
item.description: Enrique Márquez, a centrist opposition lawmaker, refused to rubber-stamp the government’s dubious election results in front of the entire nation.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Federico Parra/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The former Venezuelan presidential candidate Enrique Márquez looking at a voting record during a news conference in the capital, Caracas, in 2024.

item.title: U.S. Boards Another Tanker Carrying Venezuelan Oil
item.description: The tanker, the Olina, is the fifth to be boarded or seized by U.S. forces in recent weeks as part of an effort to control Venezuela’s oil exports.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maryorin Mendez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Silhouettes of children carrying a net at a fishing pier while in the background a crude oil tanker is docking in Venezuela’s Maracaibo Lake on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Leo Rebukes a Spreading Global ‘Zeal for War’
item.description: The pontiff used an annual address to ambassadors to the Vatican to condemn countries that prioritized violence over diplomacy to achieve their goals.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Filippo Monteforte/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV in Vatican City on Thursday. On Friday he urged nations to commit to work together to follow international laws.

item.title: Landfill Collapse in Philippines Leaves 4 Dead and Dozens Missing
item.description: A garbage mound outside Cebu City in the central Philippines collapsed on Thursday. Rescuers were searching for 34 missing people, including some trapped under the debris.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Jacqueline Hernandez/Associated Press
item.media:description: The huge mound of garbage at a waste facility in Binaliw in the Philippines on Friday, the day after it collapsed.

item.title: What Is the Oreshnik Ballistic Missile Russia Used in a Strike on Ukraine?
item.description: The attack was just the second time that Moscow had launched the nuclear-capable intermediate-range ballistic weapon.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin is seen on a screen at a military parade on Victory Day in Moscow in 2024.

item.title: Trump Indicates He Will Meet Venezuela’s Machado After Offer to Give Him Her Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: President Trump indicated that he would meet the Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado. Last year, she won the Nobel Peace Prize, an award he covets.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, at an election rally in Caracas in 2024.

item.title: Runway Wall Caused All the Deaths in 2024 South Korean Plane Crash, Report Says
item.description: A computer simulation ordered by the government showed that everyone on board would have survived if the concrete berm had been made of materials that easily broke apart.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The concrete wall at the end of the runway that the Jeju Air plane hit at Muan International Airport in 2024. A computer simulation concluded that everyone would have survived if it had been made of breakable materials.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Vows to ‘Not Back Down’ as Protests Swell
item.description: After days of fierce protest, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei accused protesters of trying to “please” President Trump. Iranian authorities signaled further crackdowns on the demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Leily Nikounazar and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Office Of The Iranian Supreme Leader, via Reuters
item.media:description: A picture made available by the office of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Saturday.

item.title: How an Abrupt Call Between Trump and Colombia’s President Averted a Crisis
item.description: President Gustavo Petro said that the new tone between the leaders was “friendly,” but he also resurfaced his deep disagreements with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia at the Presidential Palace in Bogotá, on Thursday, during an interview with The New York Times.

item.title: In Venezuela, Trump Revives ‘Gunboat Diplomacy.’ What Is It?
item.description: The U.S. campaign in Venezuela has drawn from a centuries-old playbook employing naval force — but added some new elements, too.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. Navy vessel off the coast of Puerto Rico last month. The U.S. Navy has been part of an American military buildup in the Caribbean.

item.title: Inside Myanmar’s Gilded Capital, Empty Streets and Moldy Corners
item.description: Myanmar’s junta created a capital to withstand an invasion. Now, the military struggles to project an image of control over a crumbling nation.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: An empty road in front of decommissioned tanks at the Defense Services Museum complex in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, the day after a vote in December.

item.title: Russia Says It Used Nuclear-Capable Missile to Strike Western Ukraine
item.description: The attack seemed intended to send a message to Europe as it strongly backs Kyiv in the peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to an apartment building in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, after a presumed drone strike on Friday.

item.title: Venezuelans Decry Civilian Casualties. Pentagon Says It’s Unaware of Any.
item.description: For all Venezuelans, the nighttime raid opened a period of deep uncertainty. For the families of those killed, it meant the grim task of burying their relatives.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends and family at the burial of Rosa Elena González, 80, who was killed during the U.S. raid to capture Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Once Again, a Newfoundland Town Rescues Stranded Passengers
item.description: After 9/11, Gander took in thousands of people whose flights were diverted. History repeated on a smaller scale this week.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The airport in Gander, Newfoundland, where three flights were diverted this week for bad weather, stranding travelers.
